t:summary.p: Pie charts are useful for performing relative comparisons: how do the parts make up the whole? An alternative to pie is the donut chart.
Bar charts are used for plotting data which has discrete values. The lengths of the bars are proportional to the values that they represent.
Box plots are used to represent data distributions provided a five-number summary statistic.
Dot charts consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale. It is a good alternative to the horizontal bar chart, in that it is less cluttered and redundant.
Line charts are often used to visualize time series data.
Stacked line charts are line charts in which lines do not overlap because they are stacked at each point. This way, what you see is the trend of the contribution of each value over time.
Stacked area charts are useful for displaying the trend of contribution of values of two or more variables to the total over categories or time.
A heat-grid is a colored matrix that displays a two-dimensional data-set. The intensity or the color of each cell depends on the value that it represents.
Waterfall charts are an alternative to pie charts for displaying distributions.

However when it's time to compare the size of categories and sub-categories, waterfall are the most convenient representation. While in a pie-chart you would have to compare wedges at different angles, in a waterfall chart you just compare the size of bars as all bars are parallel to one another.
Bullet Charts are a replacement for so-called gauge and meter charts (think gas gauge and thermometer).

They compare a given quantitative measure (such as profit or revenue) against qualitative ranges (e.g., poor, satisfactory, good) and related markers (e.g. the same measure a year ago), as typically found in a gauge-type chart into a much smaller space with a much higher data density.

t:summary.p: Metrics charts are similar to line graphs in that they use horizontal and vertical axes to plot data points.
However, the base axis of metric charts is always continuous, instead of discrete, as in categorical charts. They both have a continuous orthogonal axis.

The big difference is that categorical charts group data points by category (base) value and show only one visual element per unique category value. Metric charts show a distinct visual element for each data point, whether their category value occurs in other data points or not.
Metrics charts can show you, visually, the strength, shape or the direction of the relationship between variables, and whether there are outliers in the data.
Treemap charts display hierarchical data using nested rectangles. They excel in revealing the location of valuable areas buried in a deep hierarchy.
The root data node is represented by the root rectangle, which occupies the whole plot area.

The area of a leaf node is proportional to the percentage of the size dimension over its sibling nodes. The area of a non-leaf node is the sum of the areas of its child nodes. If no size dimension is specified, then all sibling-leaf nodes will have identical areas.

Rectangles are usually colored so that siblings have the same color. This way, it is easy to identify sibling nodes and compare their relative sizes. In this way, the colors that are shown are the colors of leaf nodes' parents.
Sunburst charts display hierarchical data using series of rings. They are great to quickly drill down trough a deep hierarchy, while still maintaining the notion of its dimension.
Each ring represents the children of the ring it encloses and the area of each slice corresponds to its value.
